statement.text: The smallest momenta involve single photons and ultracold atoms. A single red photon has momentum p = h/λ ≈ 10⁻²⁷ kg·m/s. Ultracold atoms at nanokelvin have p ≈ √(mk_B T) ~ 10⁻²⁸ kg·m/s. Recoil from a single photon absorption is routinely measured in precision experiments. There is NO fundamental minimum momentum—de Broglie wavelength can be arbitrarily long. The Planck momentum (pₚ ≈ 6.5 kg·m/s) is NOT minimum—it's substantial, like throwing a baseball.
statement.formal: Single red photon: p = h/λ ≈ 10⁻²⁷ kg·m/s; Ultracold atom: p ~ √(mk_B T) ≈ 10⁻²⁸ kg·m/s; Planck: pₚ = ℏ/ℓₚ ≈ 6.5 kg·m/s

explanation.intuition: Momentum p = mv or p = h/λ. The smallest momenta correspond to slow-moving particles or long-wavelength photons. Ultracold atoms in BEC have speeds of mm/s, giving tiny momenta. Radio wave photons have even smaller momenta. The Planck momentum (~6.5 kg·m/s) is NOT minimum—it's like the momentum of a thrown ball.
explanation.key_insight: There is no minimum momentum because velocity can approach zero. The quantum limit is set by Heisenberg: Δx·Δp ≥ ℏ/2. For a system confined to size L, minimum momentum uncertainty is ~ℏ/L. Photon recoil experiments measure momentum to ~10⁻³⁰ kg·m/s precision for fundamental physics tests.

comparison_with_planck.interpretation: Planck momentum is substantial—like a 0.5 kg ball thrown at 13 m/s. It's NOT a minimum.

related.relationship: Planck momentum is NOT minimum—it's 6.5 kg·m/s
p = mv connects mass and momentum
